Both of these letters are extant 111 the Bibliotheca Patrum (p. 3. tom. 5), the names also of the Bishops being subscribed who are thought to have been at these councils. But the things which are boasted of in the name of these councils are not of much moment, since for the most part they rest merely on the veracity of the heretic Faustus. For if you set aside these letters of Faustus, you may in vain seek elsewhere the afore-men— tioned decrees of the Council of Arles, as they are no where else to be found. Nor can those new deorees about preaching, of which Lucidus speaks in his epistle, be found among the canons of any Council of Leyden.
